text: today on applied science i'd like to
show you this project that i've been
working on
this is a bite sensor for a computer
human interface
so you might want this for a lot of
different reasons but this particular
one was built for a musician who doesn't
have the use of his legs
but still needs to control the sustained
pedal for his digital piano
so in this video it's going to be a mix
of different construction techniques
3d printing rapid prototyping and a
little bit of design philosophy
i thought i had a perfect solution and
it turned out to have pretty big
problems and so this philosophy of build
first and ask questions later i think is
especially apparent here also i
apologize for the lack of videos
recently
this is due in part to my shop being

on christmas night and the burglar found

strangely and thankfully he didn't steal
anything super expensive or difficult to

mostly just hand tools and power tools
and my
homeowners insurance policy has been
very helpful and we're almost back up to

a little bit of a bump in the road there
the story of this project began when a
musician contacted me and showed me his
existing setup for controlling his piano
and that was literally just a micro
switch like this that he would bite on
to control
the stain function the sustained pedal
of his digital piano

annoying i mean it's basically just on
off control

allow the pedal to be continuously
controlled
so stepping on it halfway gives you a
different effect or whether you step on

dimensionality in playing and i can see
that being
a pretty important part of this so the
challenge here
this whole project is to make a

and has a continuous output

roland's digital
digital piano now we don't know what's

pot and it's wired up to the three
terminals here there's no active
circuitry in this pedal
however if we wanted to build something
that was active and
electrically connected to the digital
piano we would have to know a lot more
about what's going on

using an ad converter that's 5 volts or
3.3 volts or
maybe it's an rc oscillator and they
measure the frequency we just don't know
and so any sort of solution we come up
with is going to be
probably have to be passive just a
potentiometer because any sort of

has a pretty high likelihood of not

it's not like you have a

that's a good way to get some isolation

it's just not really that elegant so

if it has a crappy sort of response to
